abstract: The I.M.F. does not use the term default. But missing the payment might lead to a situation in which other Greek debts are classified as defaults.

lead_paragraph: When borrowers — whether they are countries, companies or individuals — do not pay their debts on time, they are in default. For practical purposes, then, Greece — which on Tuesday failed to make a scheduled debt repayment of about 1.5 billion euros, or $1.7 billion, to the International Monetary Fund — has defaulted.

headline.main: Greece Is Placed in ‘Arrears,’ as the I.M.F. Spells ‘Default’

lead_paragraph: With the Greek “no” vote on the economic demands of its creditors on Sunday, attention now turns to the European Central Bank. abstract: The fabulist behind the popular Twitter account @GSElevator, has little of interest to convey, embellished or otherwise.
snippet: The fabulist behind the popular Twitter account @GSElevator, has little of interest to convey, embellished or otherwise.
lead_paragraph: It turned out that John LeFevre was not only never a Goldman Sachs employee, he didn’t work at any investment bank when he started the notorious anonymous Twitter account @GSElevator — which stands for Goldman Sachs elevator — in 2011. What’s more, he had not worked in New York at all for almost a decade, although he previously worked his way up to a midlevel position on the Citigroup debt syndicate desk. For all but a brief period after his analyst training program, Mr. LeFevre was relegated to a series of international Citigroup outposts. So when his identity was revealed, it surprised no one that his lucrative book contract was canceled.

headline.main: John LeFevre’s Memoir of Banking Debauchery Elicits Mostly Yawns

abstract: Greece is expected to pay 4.25 billion euros due on bonds; later this week, earnings reports will be announced by Apple, Morgan Stanley, Credit Suisse and General Motors.
snippet: Greece is expected to pay 4.25 billion euros due on bonds; later this week, earnings reports will be announced by Apple, Morgan Stanley, Credit Suisse and General Motors.
lead_paragraph: After receiving a short-term loan from the European Union last week, Greece is expected to pay 4.25 billion euros ($4.6 billion) due on bonds held by the European Central Bank, as well as €2 billion in overdue payments to the International Monetary Fund. Failure to pay the E.C.B. would have forced the bank to cut off emergency funding for Greek banks, causing them and the Greek economy to collapse. The debt payments represent a step back from the precipice of a eurozone exit for Greece, but the government led by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras must cope this week with the political turmoil caused by his decision to accept unpleasant conditions set by eurozone creditors in return for financial aid. In a move toward normalcy, Greek banks reopened on Monday. —Jack Ewing

headline.main: Greece’s Debt Payments, Apple Earnings and Credit Suisse Results

abstract: Fiat Chrysler is recalling about 350,000 Journey sport utility vehicles because a plastic engine cover could come loose, contact a hot exhaust and cause a fire.
snippet: Fiat Chrysler is recalling about 350,000 Journey sport utility vehicles because a plastic engine cover could come loose, contact a hot exhaust and cause a fire.
lead_paragraph: Fiat Chrysler is recalling about 350,000 Journey sport utility vehicles, including about 144,000 in the United States, because a plastic engine cover could come loose, contact a hot exhaust and cause a fire, the automaker said on Wednesday. Three fires in Chile resulting in one “minor” injury prompted the automaker’s investigation, a spokesman for Chrysler, Eric Mayne, said in an email. He said eight vehicles in the United States have had the problem, but while there was heat damage, there were no fires. The recalled vehicles are the four-cylinder models of the 2011-15 Dodge Journey, and a sibling sold outside North America as the Fiat Fremont.

headline.main: Fire Risk Prompts Fiat Chrysler to Recall 350,000 Vehicles
headline.print_headline: Fire Risk Prompts Fiat Chrysler to Recall 350,000 Vehicles

lead_paragraph: In the last few years, I’ve watched a continuing battle among my friends about which is worse for you: artificial sweeteners or sugar. Unless you want to forgo all beverages that are sweet, you’re going to run into one of these. Rather than rely on anecdote or myth, we can inform this debate with research.

headline.main: The Evidence Supports Artificial Sweeteners Over Sugar
headline.print_headline: If You Drink Soda, Choose Artificially Sweetened

abstract: A travel puzzle by Terence Tao, one of the world’s greatest living mathematicians.
snippet: A travel puzzle by Terence Tao, one of the world’s greatest living mathematicians.
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle is by Terence Tao, an Australian-born mathematician and current professor at the University of California, Los Angeles. Dr. Tao is truly remarkable. Research mathematicians often see themselves as falling into two categories: technicians — those who can bring rigor, precision and clarity to a solution, and magicians, who open entirely new fields of inquiry. Dr. Tao can do both. “He’s a rock star,” said Ravi Vakil, a four-time Putnam winner who’s known Dr. Tao for years. “Brilliant, collaborative, maintains the best blog in mathematics. I’m not sure how he does it.” The computer science legend Donald Knuth was even more pointed. “Terry Tao is the current paradigm in mathematics,” he told me recently.

headline.main: Terence Tao’s Airport-Inspired Puzzle
